user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_digest_auth_get_username3:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo *
MHD_digest_auth_get_username3 (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params;
  struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo *uname_info;
  enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType uname_type;
  size_t unif_buf_size;
  uint8_t *unif_buf_ptr;
  size_t unif_buf_used;

  params = MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_ (connection);
  if (NULL == params)
    return NULL;

  uname_type = get_rq_uname_type (params);
  if ( (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_MISSING == uname_type) ||
       (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID == uname_type) )
    return NULL;

  unif_buf_size = get_rq_unames_size (params, uname_type);

  uname_info = (struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo *)
               MHD_calloc_ (1, (sizeof(struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo))
                            + unif_buf_size);
  unif_buf_ptr = (uint8_t *) (uname_info + 1);
  unif_buf_used = get_rq_uname (params, uname_type, uname_info, unif_buf_ptr,
                                unif_buf_size);
  mhd_assert (unif_buf_size >= unif_buf_used);
  (void) unif_buf_used; /* Mute compiler warning on non-debug builds */
  mhd_assert (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_MISSING != uname_info->uname_type);

  if (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_INVALID == uname_info->uname_type)
  {
    free (uname_info);
    return NULL;
  }
  mhd_assert (uname_type == uname_info->uname_type);
  uname_info->algo3 = params->algo3;

  return uname_info;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function has a single parameter: "struct MHD_Connection *connection". Scanning the body shows no assignment to the parameter variable (no occurrences of "connection = ...", no pointer arithmetic on connection, no reassignments or mutations of the pointer itself). Calls that pass connection (MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_(connection)) may operate on the object pointed to — which is permitted by Rule 17.8 — but the pointer parameter is not modified in this function. All other pointer writes (e.g., writing into uname_info, unif_buf_ptr) operate on local variables/allocated objects, not on a function parameter. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and nothing else needs investigation with respect to this rule.
